Award.AwardTitle: SL-CN: Development of Neural Body Maps

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
A great deal of research with adults has documented the presence of body maps in the human brain. These neural maps have an organized spatial layout. Neighboring parts of the body are connected in an orderly fashion to areas of the brain that process touch and movement. Body maps are important for many aspect of everyday life including the sense of one's own body and controlling our movements. Body maps also likely play an important role in learning from others, through allowing us to register similarities between ourselves and other people. Despite the importance of body maps, very little is currently understood about how they develop in the early months and years of life. The research supported by this award would provide significant new information on the development of body maps and their relation to early learning. The award supports a collaborative, cross-disciplinary network of investigators who will combine expertise in developmental psychology and infant learning, brain science, cognitive science, computer modelling, and robotics. The proposed network will also support the development and training of junior investigators through specific activities designed to expose them to the benefits of an interdisciplinary approach.

Advances in methods for safely measuring the brain activity of human infants are allowing new questions to be asked concerning the role of body maps in early learning. The proposed research involves using magnetoencephalography (MEG) to non-invasively measure responses of the infant brain to tactile stimulation of different parts of the body (e.g., hands vs. feet), and to relate these responses to aspects of infant learning. Another set of studies involving electroencephalography (EEG) will examine how body maps facilitate early imitation and learning from others. Insights from these studies will inform (and be informed by) a further strain of research using computer modelling that takes bodily factors into account in designing robotic systems that can learn from people. The research questions will also provide insight into the control of brain-computer interfaces that can assist disabled individuals in learning to control artificial limbs and other external devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major specific goals of this project were to explore the processes through which neural body maps are established, maintained, and modified in human infancy. Body maps were studied from multiple angles, combining work in developmental science, cognitive neuroscience, AI and physics (through the use of MEG).

The past decade has seen sustained interest in the neural processes involved in the perception of the human body. Studies in adult participants have illuminated the brain networks contributing to the sense of body ownership and have documented cortical regions associated with perceiving bodies of other people. Historically, the representation of one's own body and the perception of the bodies of others have often been studied independently. Growing attention is now being paid to the interconnections between them, including the role of neural representations of the body in adult social cognition.

Although research with adults and animals is providing insights into interpersonal aspects of body representations, developmental studies have been scarce. The specific goal of this grant was to expand our knowledge about the development of neural infant body maps. Novel applications of methods for recording infant brain activity (MEG) were used in addition to more standard measures (EEG). We hypothesized that infants' developing body maps play a foundational role in the origins and early development of social cognition. We further hypothesized that advances in understanding the body scheme in human infancy will be informative in advancing computer science, robotics, and AI, because key questions concern the importance of 'the body' for modeling and simulating human cognition.

We made good progress in conducting interdisciplinary research on infant neural body maps. We, and others, have helped to bring the study of infant body representations from a minimally studied sub-field to one of the more rapidly growing aspects of developmental cognitive neuroscience. At the more tangible level, one measure of the success and intellectual merit of this grant has been in the publications it produced in high-profile peer-reviewed venues. There were 11 peer-reviewed journal papers engendered by this grant.

At a more granular level, we published two synthetic theoretical papers (Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 2015, and Current Opinion in the Behavioral Sciences, 2018). We also published studies using two neuroscience techniques, both magnetoencephalography (MEG) and electroencephalography (EEG). Our work using MEG was done in conjunction with physicists at the University of Washington and incorporated state-of-the-art techniques for correcting for head-movement and also for source localization. Our EEG work helped pioneer the use of MMN (well-established in auditory perception) so that it could be used to examine the somatosensory modality (sMMN) in infants. We then applied sMMN to study body segmentation and categorization in both adults and infants.

One of our most interesting empirical findings involved using MEG to investigate both felt and observed touch in 29-week-old infants. Experiment 1 evaluated the spatiotemporal organization of infants' brain responses to being touched. A punctate touch to infants' hands and feet produced significant activation in the hand and foot areas of contralateral primary somatosensory cortex as well as in other parietal and frontal areas. Experiment 2 explored infant brain responses to visually perceiving another person's hand or foot being touched. Results showed significant activation in early visual regions and also in regions thought to be involved in multisensory body and self-other processing. Furthermore, observed touch of the hand and foot activated the infant's own primary somatosensory cortex, although less consistently than felt touch. These findings shed light on aspects of early social cognition, including action imitation, which may build, at least in part, on infant neural representations that map equivalences between the bodies of self and other.

Another noteworth finding involved using electroencephalography (EEG) with 60-day-old infants to test the distribution of brain responses to tactile stimulation of three different body parts: hand, foot, and lip. Analyses focused on a prominent positive response occurring at 150-200 ms in the somatosensory evoked potential at central and parietal electrodes. Results showed differential neural signatures for touch of these three body parts. Stimulation of the left hand was associated with greater positive amplitude over the lateral central region contralateral to the side stimulated. Left foot stimulation was associated with greater positivity over the midline parietal site. Stimulation of the midline of the lip was associated with a strong bilateral response over the central region. These findings provide insights into the neural representation of the body in infancy and shed light on theories about the involvement of somatosensory cortex in infant social perception.

This grant has also had significant evidence of broader impact. It spawned an interdisciplinary symposium at the AAAS 2020 meeting, "Communication Through Touch: From Babies to Social Robots." Other evidence of broader impact includes press coverage in venues including on the NSF website and in print and electronic media  (e.g., New York Times, Wall Street Journal).
